Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an EPR Spectrometer for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Miroslav Peric from California State University Northridge and colleagues Radha Ranganathan and Jussi Eloranta have acquired an X-band electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer. This instrument will allow research in a variety of fields such as those that provide insight on how biologically relevant species behave as well as advance environmental studies. In general, an EPR spectrometer yields detailed information on the geometric and electronic structure of molecular and solid state materials. It is also used to obtain information about the lifetimes of free radicals, short-lived, highly reactive species involved in valuable chemical transformations as well as the initiation of pathological tumor growth. These studies impact a number of areas, from the synthesis of inorganic and organic molecules to the development of new solid state materials to compounds of magnetic and biological interest. Employing examples inspired from ongoing research, this instrument is an integral part of research and teaching at California State University Northridge. The instrument provides students with outstanding practical experience in modern instrumentation.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as studying (a) translational and rotational diffusion of spin nitroxide probes in protein-phospholipid aggregates and ionic liquids; (b) mechanistic and kinetic studies of radical intermediates in wastewater treatment; (c) physicochemical characterization of molecular aggregates; (d) electron rich aromatic and diene interactions with electron-poor imidazolium compounds; (e) bimolecular collisions in low-viscosity liquids and (f) solute jump diffusion in supercooled water.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report - NSF Award# 1626632

Project Title: MRI: Acquisition of an EPR Spectrometer for Research and Education

Awardee: The University Corporation, Northridge

Project/Grant Period: 08/10/2016 - 07/31/2019

Investigator(s): Miroslav Peric miroslav.peric@csun.edu (PI)

                        Radha Ranganathan (Co-PI)

                        Jussi Eloranta (Co-PI)

 

This project enabled the PI and Co-PIs to acquire a state of the art X-band electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer.  The acquired EPR spectrometer is expected to improve the quality and the quantity of research performed at Califonia State University Northridge (CSUN) and further enhance CSUN faculty's ability to attract external funding, pursue collaborative research opportunities and enable CSUN's diverse student body the valuable opportunity of hands-on training and research experience. The project benefits research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as studying (a) translational and rotational diffusion of spin nitroxide probes in protein-phospholipid aggregates and ionic liquids; (b) mechanistic and kinetic studies of radical intermediates in wastewater treatment; (c) physicochemical characterization of molecular aggregates; (d) electron-rich aromatic and diene interactions with electron-poor imidazolium compounds; (e) bimolecular collisions in low-viscosity liquids and (f) solute jump diffusion in supercooled water.

The EPR spectrometer is used in three major areas of education at CSUN, which are (1) courses to train CSUN's students in modern spectroscopic methods (2) research activities, and (3) providing access to instrumentation for students who are traditionally underrepresented in science. More than forty undergraduate students were enrolled in the courses that used the EPR spectrometer. The students learned the theory of EPR spectroscopy, as well as how the EPR method can be used in industry and research. They were trained to use EasySpin software. EasySpin was used to simulate EPR spectra and to fit experimental EPR spectra.  Also, the students had to write a program to solve the modified Bloch equations using Matlab. The students were trained to use the EMXplus EPR spectrometer and performed several experiments using it. Two MS graduate students used the EPR spectrometer in their MA thesis projects. Offering undergraduate and graduate students the training and the modern experimental tools to do research in the laboratory will ultimately help them succeed in their educational and career pursuits.

In research, the spectrometer has been and will be used to study the physicochemical properties of ionic liquids. Ionic liquids, substances made up of ions, have become a viable alternative to molecular solvents due to their interesting and peculiar physicochemical properties, which makes them the solvents of choice in many applications. A new method developed at CSU Northridge has successfully been used to study the translational diffusion of nitroxide solute molecules in a variety of ionic liquids. The results of this study show how the presence of free volume in an ionic liquid affects its transport properties. Hopefully, this method will be used by other EPR groups to study the physicochemical properties of ionic liquids and other viscous liquids. Also, the EPR spectrometer has been used to study the phase transitions behavior and crystal structures of paramagnetic ionic liquids.

In conclusion, improving the experimental infrastructure at CSU Northridge will enable new research opportunities and collaborations not only for the involved faculty members but also for their undergraduate and MS graduate students. Also, it will improve educational activities and learning in undergraduate and MS graduate courses at CSU Northridge.
